title: 11's remainders

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \begin{aligned} S_1 & = \sum_{n=6}^{10} (2n+1)^{n-5} \\ & = \sum_{n=1}^5 (2n+11)^n \\ \implies S_1 & \equiv \sum_{n=1}^5 (2n)^n \pmod {11} \\ & \equiv (2^1+4^2+6^3+8^4+10^5) \pmod {11} \\ & \equiv (2+5+(-5)^3+(-3)^4+(-1)^5) \pmod {11} \\ & \equiv (2+5-4+4-1) \pmod {11} \\ & \equiv 6 \pmod {11} \end{aligned}  "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \begin{aligned} S_2 & = \sum_{n=6}^{10} (2n)^{n-5} \\ & = \sum_{n=1}^5 (2n+10)^n \\ \implies S_2 & \equiv \sum_{n=1}^5 (2n-1)^n \pmod {11} \\ & \equiv (1^1+3^2+5^3+7^4+9^5) \pmod {11} \\ & \equiv (1+9+4+(-4)^4+(-2)^5) \pmod {11} \\ & \equiv (1+9+4+3-10) \pmod {11} \\ & \equiv 7 \pmod {11} \end{aligned}  "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore, we have:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \begin{aligned} a^4b^4 & \equiv 6^47^4 \pmod{11} \\ & \equiv 42^4 \pmod{11} \\ & \equiv (-2)^4 \pmod{11} \\ & \equiv \boxed{5} \pmod{11} \end{aligned}  "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We can make a multiplication from the outset, but we can also use mathematical induction which, in this case, is quicker. The first line, the amount of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in square is two digits, hence the square being from 1 to 2 then reverse (without repetition of 2) to 1. Similarly, in the second line, the amount of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in square is three digits, hence the square being from 1 to 3 then reverse (without repetition of 3) to 1."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hence, the amount of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in square is five digits, hence the square being from 1 to 5 then reverse (without repetition of 5) to 1, or by spelling out, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"123454321"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: "When I was 4"
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large{xy+\frac{x^3+y^3}{3}=2007}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ordered pairs "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(x,y)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" of integers satisfying the equation above.
If the set of all such pairs are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \{ (x_1, y_1), (x_2, y_2), \ldots , (x_n, y_n) \} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then find the value of:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large{\sum_{i=1}^n (x_i + y_i) = \ ? }"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We use the factorisation "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^3+y^3+z^3-3xyz=(x+y+z)(x^2+y^2+z^2-xy-yz-zx)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned} \dfrac{x^3+y^3}{3} +xy &= 2007\\
x^3+y^3+3xy &= 6021\\
x^3+y^3+(-1)^3 - 3xy(-1) &= 6020\\
(x+y-1)(x^2+y^2+1-xy+x+y) &= 6020\\
(x+y-1)((x+y-1)^2 - 3xy - 3x - 3y) &= 2^2 \times 5 \times 7 \times 43
\end{aligned}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since the RHS "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\equiv 2 \pmod{3}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", the LHS must also be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\equiv 2 \pmod{3}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Thus, we must have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x+y-1 \equiv 2 \pmod{3}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". All positive factors of 6020 that are equivalent to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2 \pmod{3}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"14"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"20"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"35"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"86"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"140"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"215"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"602"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"860"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1505"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"6020"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". By observation, we get that only "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x+y-1=20"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" satisfies, with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=18"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y=3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" or vice-versa. Thus, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x+y=21"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", but since we're looking for ordered pairs, the answer is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{42}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 6021 =x^3 + y^3 + 3xy = (x+y)^3 - 3xy(x+y) + 3xy "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
we see that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x+y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is divisible by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". But then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3xy = 6021 + 3xy(x+y) - (x+y)^3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is divisible by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" divides "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"xy"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Thus both "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are divisible by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=3X"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y=3Y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" where
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \begin{aligned}
6021 & = \; 27(X+Y)^3 - 81XY(X+Y) + 27XY \\
27XY & = \; \frac{27(X+Y)^3 - 6021}{3(X+Y) - 1} \; = \; 9(X+Y)^2 + 3(X+Y) + 1 - \frac{6020}{3(X+Y)-1}
\end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
so we deduce that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3(X+Y)-1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" divides "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"6020"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Possible values of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X+Y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and therefore "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"XY"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", are thus"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline
X+Y & XY & X+Y & XY & X+Y & XY & X+Y & XY \\ \hline
-1003 & 335225 & -401 & 53556 & -143 & 6801 & -100 & 3323 \\
-57 & 1078 & -23 & 177 & -14 & 69 & -9 & 34 \\
-3 & 25 & -2 & 33 & -1 & 56 & 0 & 223 \\
1 & -111 & 2 & -43 & 5 & -7 & 7 & 6 \\
12 & 43  &29 & 281 & 47 & 740 & 72 & 1735 \\
201 & 13489 & 287 & 27488 & 502 & 84057 & 2007 & 1342906  \\ \hline
\end{array} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Of these, only the pair "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X+Y=7"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"XY= 6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" correspond to integer solutions "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X,Y = 1,6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Thus the only solutions to the equation are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(x_1,y_1) = (18,3)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(x_2,y_2) = (3,18)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which makes the answer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{42}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

replies.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Oh and here the factorization is actually quite trivial, remember the identity "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" x^3 + y^3 + z^3 - 3xyz = (x + y + z)(x^2 + y^2 + z^2 - xy - yz - zx) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", now it is easy to see that by choosing "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"z = -1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  we get  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" x^3 + y^3 - 1 + 3xy = (x + y - 1)(x^2 + y^2 + 1 - xy + y + x) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In general we could look for a possible linear factor "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" (ax + by + c) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to the polynomial and if that fails, quadratic, and so on with multiple variables also.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Yes you could fact this way. It was interesting, nonetheless, to note that both "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" had to be multiples of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Couldn't you already use "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 3xy = 6021 + 3xy(x+y) - (x+y)^3 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to get  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 3xy = ((x+y)^2 + (x + y) + 1) - \dfrac{6020}{ (x + y) - 1 } "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" which leads to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" x + y - 1 \mid 6020"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"?"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Your method of solving this is similar to finding a factorization "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" (x + y - 1)(x^2 - xy + y^2 + x + y + 1) = 6020 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"which simplifies the problem of solving "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" x^3 + 3xy + y^3 = 6021 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to factoring the left hand side of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" x^3 + 3xy + y^3 + C = 6021 + C "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for some constant "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"C"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" which again is a common method of solving diophantine equations.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a=b a^2=a.b a^2-b^2 =ab-b^2 (a-b)(a+b) = b(a-b)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Everything is right so far. Logically, the next step will be to divide both sides by a-b, as this is the common term. However, a=b. Therefore a-b =0. Since one cannot divide anything by 0, one cannot divide the expression by a-b."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a=b
a^2=a.b
a^2-b^2 =ab-b^2 
(a-b)(a+b) = b(a-b)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Everything is right so far.  Logically, the next step will be to divide both sides by a-b, as this is the common term. However, a=b. Therefore a-b =0. Since one cannot divide anything by 0, one cannot divide the expression by a-b."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A farmer's wife made some chapatis...the farmer had 3 sons....  The fist son came, gave one chapati to the dog,and made three equal parts of remaining chapatis, ate one part of it and left the other two parts for his brothers....other two sons  came one after the other and did the same thinking that they came first...then at night all three came to the house,one of them gave one chapati to dog and made three equal parts and the three brothers ate one-one part of it... If no chapati was broken in pieces then how many chapatis did the mom made??\ntry to solve without calc.."}]}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac {1}{10} > \frac {1}{100}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ln \frac {1}{10} > ln \frac {1}{100}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
 "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ln \frac {1}{10} > ln (\frac {1}{10})^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ln \frac {1}{10} > 2 \cdot ln (\frac {1}{10})"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"      "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Cancelling "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ln(\frac {1}{10})"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we obtain "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 > 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What option explains the mistake?"}]}]}

replies.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            yup the options are a bit confusing but on thinking we get that because ln(.1) is negative we cannot cancel it without changing the sign of the inequality.
we can understand this as "ln(.1) being negative is the cause of this cancelling"
Yeah i know its confusing but can't explain it here just by typing

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            If you do cancel the ln from both sides, the inequality sign must be flipped, because you are dividing by a negative. Thus, the result would be 2 > 1

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

                                            The answer is  not correct (or the options are  misleading) 
e.g.      -5  > -6 "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
you can't  remove  -ve   sign because this will lead to    5 > 6"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"my answer was you can not cancel  (ln n) in this case >>> 

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Dividing both sides of the inequality by a negative number changes the inequality symbol to its opposite.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

title: 1200 followers problem!
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Consider a 1200 digit number "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N_a=\underbrace{aaaa\dots aaa}_{\text{1200 } a\text{'s}  }"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Define "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\varphi_a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" as the number of zeroes in the decimal representation of the quotient obtained when "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N_a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is divided by 37."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Compute "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle\sum_{a=1}^9 \varphi_a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Bonus:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" Generalize this."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"First observe that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"37 \ | \ 111"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"37 \ | \ \overline{aaa}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1200"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a multiple of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ,"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N_a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"'s decimal representation can be grouped as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"400"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" parts of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"aaa"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".So , when "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N_a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is divided by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\overline{aaa}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" the quotient will be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\overline{1001001001\dots 001001}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" with no remainder. Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \overline{aaa} \ | \ N_a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"37 \ | \ \overline{aaa}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" , we have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"37 \ | \ N_a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Observe that :"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"37 \times 3 = 111 \\ 37 \times 6 = 222 \\ 37 \times 9 = 333 \\ 37 \times 12 = 444 \\ 37 \times 15 = 555 \\ 37 \times 18 = 666 \\ 37 \times 21 = 777 \\ 37 \times 24 = 888 \\ 37 \times 27 = 999 "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"When "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\overline{aaa}=37\delta_a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\delta_a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a one digit number of form "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3a \forall \ a \ , \ 1\leq a \leq 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" , the quotient when "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N_a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is divided by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"37"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" will be of form "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\overline{\delta_a00\delta_a00\delta_a\dots00\delta_a}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"00\delta_a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" appears "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"399"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" times , which means "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" appears "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(399 \times 2)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for 1 value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1\leq a \leq 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" we have :"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow\Large\displaystyle\sum_{a=1}^3 \varphi_a= 399 \times 6"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"When "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\overline{aaa}=37\delta_a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\delta_a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a two digit number of form "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3a \forall \ a \ , \ 4\leq a \leq 9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" , the quotient when "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N_a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is divided by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"37"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" will be of form "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\overline{\delta_a0\delta_a0\delta_a\dots0\delta_a}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0\delta_a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" appears "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"399"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" times , which means "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" appears "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(399) \ times"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for 1 value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4\leq a \leq 9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" , we have: "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow\Large\displaystyle\sum_{a=4}^9 \varphi_a =399 \times 6"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow\Large\displaystyle\sum_{a=1}^9 \varphi_a = 2(399\times 6) = 399\times 12 = \boxed{4788}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            So, a stronger generalization would be, for a "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"-digit number "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N_a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3\mid x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N_a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is defined for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a\in\Bbb{Z^+_{\leq 9}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" as given in the problem, we have,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\varphi_a=\begin{cases}\begin{array}{ccc}2\left(\dfrac x3-1\right)&\forall&1\leq a\leq 3\\ \dfrac x3-1&\forall&4\leq a\leq 9\end{array}\end{cases}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now, consider "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\mathcal{S_x}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" as the sum of all "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\varphi_i"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"'s for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N_x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". We have,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\mathcal{S_x}=\sum_{k=1}^9\varphi_k=\left(\sum_{k=1}^3\frac{2(x-3)}{3}\right)+\left(\sum_{k=4}^9\frac{x-3}{3}\right)\\ \implies \mathcal{S_x}=\frac 23(3x-9)+\frac 13(6x-18)=2x-6+2x-6\\ \implies \boxed{\mathcal{S_x}=4x-12=4(x-3)}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The problem posed here is finding the value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\mathcal{S}_{1200}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" which can easily be evaluated to be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4788"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Good question, and congrats for 1200 followers

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

"}],"attrs":[{"text":"c += lob.inject(0){|cs,l|l == '0' ? cs+1 : cs}
","language":null}]},{"type":"text","text":"

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"xyz"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" = ("},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"cos\alpha +isin\alpha )(cos\beta +isin\beta )(cos\gamma +isin\gamma )"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow xyz\quad =\quad cos(\alpha +\beta +\gamma )+isin(\alpha +\beta +\gamma )"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow xyz\quad =\quad cos(n\pi )+isin(n\pi )"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow xyz\quad =\quad +1\quad +\quad 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"                                                                          (when  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n\pi =\quad 0,\quad 2\pi ,\quad 4\pi \quad ....)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"OR"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"xyz\quad =\quad -1\quad +\quad 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"                                                                                                         (when   "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" n\pi =\quad 1\pi,\quad 3\pi ,\quad 5\pi \quad ....)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"[Note : If "},{"type":"text","text":"a + b + c = nπn\pinπ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" , then "},{"type":"text","text":"tan a + tan b + tan c = tan a . tan b .tan c","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" ]"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\large{\\displaystyle \\sum^{\\infty}_{n=1} \\frac{1+2015^{n}}{2016^{n}n^{2}}=\\frac{\\pi^{A}}{B}+\\ln (C) \\ln(D)-(\\ln(C))^2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If the equation is true for positive integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A,B,C"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"D"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", find "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A+B+C+D"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \begin{aligned} \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1+2015^n}{2016^n n^2} & = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{2016^n n^2} + \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{2015^n}{2016^n n^2} \\ & = \text{Li}_2 \left(\frac{1}{2016} \right) + \text{Li}_2 \left(\frac{2015}{2016} \right) \quad \quad \quad \quad \small \color{#3D99F6}{\text{Li}_2(z) \text{ is dilogarithm function}} \\ & = \text{Li}_2 \left(\frac{1}{2016} \right) + \text{Li}_2 \left(1 - \frac{1}{2016} \right) \quad \quad \small \color{#3D99F6}{\text{By Abel identity with } x =y}  \\ & = \frac{\pi^2}{6} - \ln\left(\frac{1}{2016} \right) \ln\left(1-\frac{1}{2016} \right) \\ & = \frac{\pi^2}{6} - \ln\left(\frac{1}{2016} \right) \ln\left(\frac{2015}{2016} \right) \\ & = \frac{\pi^2}{6} + \ln 2016 \ln 2015 - \ln^2 2016 \end{aligned}  "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow A+B+C+D = 2 + 6 + 2016 + 2015 = \boxed{4039}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"More about "},{"type":"text","text":"polylogarithm function and Abel identy","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}
